Display APIïƒ

The Display class is the main entry point for creating interactive trelliscope displays.

Display Classïƒ

class trelliscope.Display(data, name, description='', keysig=None, path=None)[source]ïƒ

Bases: object

Interactive visualization display for exploring collections of plots.

Each row in the input DataFrame represents one panel with associated metadata (cognostics) for filtering and sorting.

Parameters:

  • data (pd.DataFrame) â€“ DataFrame where one column contains panels (plots/figures) and other columns contain cognostics (metadata).

  • name (str) â€“ Unique identifier for this display. Must be non-empty.

  • description (str, optional) â€“ Human-readable description of the display.

  • keysig (str, optional) â€“ Unique key signature for the display. Auto-generated from data if not provided.

  • path (Path or str, optional) â€“ Output directory path. Defaults to â€˜./trelliscope_outputâ€™.

dataïƒ

Input DataFrame with panels and cognostics.

Type:

pd.DataFrame

nameïƒ

Display identifier.

Type:

str

descriptionïƒ

Display description.

Type:

str

keysigïƒ

Unique key signature.

Type:

str

pathïƒ

Output directory path.

Type:

Path

panel_columnïƒ

Column name containing panel data.

Type:

str or None

metasïƒ

Meta variable configurations.

Type:

dict

stateïƒ

Display state (layout, filters, sorts, labels).

Type:

dict

viewsïƒ

Named view configurations.

Type:

list

panel_optionsïƒ

Panel dimension options (width, height, aspect).

Type:

dict

Examples

>>> import pandas as pd
>>> from trelliscope import Display
>>>
>>> df = pd.DataFrame({
...     'plot': [fig1, fig2, fig3],
...     'category': ['A', 'B', 'C'],
...     'value': [10, 20, 30]
... })
>>>
>>> display = Display(df, name="my_display")
>>> display.set_panel_column("plot")
>>> display.write()
Raises:

  • TypeError â€“ If data is not a pandas DataFrame.

  • ValueError â€“ If name is empty or not a string.

__init__(data, name, description='', keysig=None, path=None)[source]ïƒ
set_panel_column(column)[source]ïƒ

Specify which column contains panel data (plots/figures).

Parameters:

column (str) â€“ Column name containing panels.

Returns:

Self for method chaining.

Return type:

Display

Raises:

ValueError â€“ If column does not exist in DataFrame.

Examples

>>> display = Display(df, name="example")
>>> display.set_panel_column("plot")
set_default_layout(ncol=4, nrow=None, page=1, arrangement='row')[source]ïƒ

Configure default grid layout for panels.

Parameters:

  • ncol (int, default=4) â€“ Number of columns in the grid.

  • nrow (int, optional) â€“ Number of rows in the grid. If None, calculated automatically.

  • page (int, default=1) â€“ Starting page number.

  • arrangement ({"row", "col"}, default="row") â€“ Panel arrangement order (â€œrowâ€ for row-major, â€œcolâ€ for column-major).

Returns:

Self for method chaining.

Return type:

Display

Raises:

ValueError â€“ If ncol < 1, page < 1, or arrangement not in {â€œrowâ€, â€œcolâ€}.

Examples

>>> display.set_default_layout(ncol=3, nrow=2, arrangement="row")
set_panel_options(width=None, height=None, aspect=None, force_size=False)[source]ïƒ

Configure panel dimensions and sizing behavior.

Parameters:

  • width (int, optional) â€“ Panel width in pixels.

  • height (int, optional) â€“ Panel height in pixels. Ignored if aspect is specified.

  • aspect (float, optional) â€“ Aspect ratio (width/height). Overrides height if specified.

  • force_size (bool, default=False) â€“ Force exact dimensions regardless of content.

Returns:

Self for method chaining.

Return type:

Display

Raises:

ValueError â€“ If width or height < 1, or aspect <= 0.

Examples

>>> display.set_panel_options(width=800, height=600)
>>> display.set_panel_options(width=800, aspect=1.5)  # 800x533
set_panel_interface(interface=None, **kwargs)[source]ïƒ

Configure how panels are loaded in the viewer.

Parameters:

  • interface (PanelInterface, str, or None) â€“ Panel interface configuration. Can be: - PanelInterface instance (LocalPanelInterface, RESTPanelInterface, etc.) - String type: â€œlocalâ€, â€œrestâ€, or â€œwebsocketâ€ (creates interface with **kwargs) - None: Uses default LocalPanelInterface

  • **kwargs â€“ Parameters passed to interface constructor if interface is a string.

Returns:

Self for method chaining.

Return type:

Display

Raises:

  • TypeError â€“ If interface is not a valid type.

  • ValueError â€“ If interface configuration is invalid.

Examples

>>> from trelliscope import Display, RESTPanelInterface
>>>
>>> # Using interface object
>>> interface = RESTPanelInterface(
...     base="http://localhost:5001/api/panels/my_display"
... )
>>> display.set_panel_interface(interface)
>>>
>>> # Using string shorthand
>>> display.set_panel_interface(
...     "rest",
...     base="http://localhost:5001/api/panels/my_display"
... )
>>>
>>> # Default local panels
>>> display.set_panel_interface("local", format="png")
set_default_labels(labels)[source]ïƒ

Set which meta variables to show as panel labels.

Parameters:

labels (list of str) â€“ Column names to display as labels.

Returns:

Self for method chaining.

Return type:

Display

Raises:

ValueError â€“ If any label column does not exist in DataFrame.

Examples

>>> display.set_default_labels(["category", "score"])
add_meta_variable(meta, replace=False)[source]ïƒ

Add a meta variable (cognostic) to the display.

Parameters:

  • meta (MetaVariable) â€“ Meta variable instance to add.

  • replace (bool, default=False) â€“ If True, replace existing meta with same varname. If False, raise error if meta exists.

Returns:

Self for method chaining.

Return type:

Display

Raises:

  • TypeError â€“ If meta is not a MetaVariable instance.

  • ValueError â€“ If meta.varname not in DataFrame columns, or if meta already exists and replace=False.

Examples

>>> from trelliscope import FactorMeta
>>> meta = FactorMeta("category", levels=["A", "B", "C"])
>>> display.add_meta_variable(meta)
add_meta_def(varname, meta_type, replace=False, **kwargs)[source]ïƒ

Define and add a meta variable inline using type and parameters.

Parameters:

  • varname (str) â€“ Column name for meta variable.

  • meta_type (str) â€“ Meta type: â€œfactorâ€, â€œnumberâ€, â€œdateâ€, â€œtimeâ€, â€œcurrencyâ€, â€œhrefâ€, â€œgraphâ€.

  • replace (bool, default=False) â€“ If True, replace existing meta with same varname.

  • **kwargs â€“ Additional parameters for the meta type constructor.

Returns:

Self for method chaining.

Return type:

Display

Raises:

ValueError â€“ If meta_type is unknown or varname not in DataFrame.

Examples

>>> display.add_meta_def("category", "factor", levels=["A", "B", "C"])
>>> display.add_meta_def("value", "number", digits=3, log=True)
infer_metas(columns=None, replace=False)[source]ïƒ

Automatically infer and add meta variables from DataFrame columns.

Parameters:

  • columns (list of str, optional) â€“ Columns to infer meta for. Defaults to all columns.

  • replace (bool, default=False) â€“ If True, replace existing metas for these columns.

Returns:

Self for method chaining.

Return type:

Display

Examples

>>> # Infer all columns
>>> display.infer_metas()
>>>
>>> # Infer specific columns
>>> display.infer_metas(columns=["category", "value"])
get_meta_variable(varname)[source]ïƒ

Retrieve a specific meta variable by name.

Parameters:

varname (str) â€“ Meta variable name to retrieve.

Returns:

The meta variable instance.

Return type:

MetaVariable

Raises:

KeyError â€“ If meta variable not found.

Examples

>>> meta = display.get_meta_variable("category")
>>> print(meta.type)
'factor'
get_all_meta_variables()[source]ïƒ

Get all meta variables as a dictionary.

Returns:

Dictionary mapping varnames to MetaVariable instances.

Return type:

dict

Examples

>>> metas = display.get_all_meta_variables()
>>> for varname, meta in metas.items():
...     print(f"{varname}: {meta.type}")
list_meta_variables()[source]ïƒ

List all meta variable names.

Returns:

Sorted list of meta variable names.

Return type:

list of str

Examples

>>> display.list_meta_variables()
['category', 'date', 'value']
write(output_path=None, force=False, render_panels=True, create_index=True, viewer_debug=False, use_multi_display=True)[source]ïƒ

Write display to disk as JSON specification and render panels.

Creates output directory, renders panel files, and writes displayInfo.json, metaData.json, metaData.js, metadata.csv, and index.html files.

Parameters:

  • output_path (Path or str, optional) â€“ Output directory path. Uses display.path if not provided.

  • force (bool, default=False) â€“ If True, overwrite existing output directory. If False, raise error if directory exists.

  • render_panels (bool, default=True) â€“ If True, render panel objects to files (PNG, HTML, etc.). If False, only write JSON/CSV files without rendering panels.

  • create_index (bool, default=True) â€“ If True, automatically generate index.html viewer file. If False, skip index.html generation.

  • viewer_debug (bool, default=False) â€“ If True, include debug console in index.html for troubleshooting. Only used when create_index=True.

  • use_multi_display (bool, default=True) â€“ If True, use multi-display structure with config.json and displays/ subdirectory. If False, use single-display structure (EXPERIMENTAL).

Returns:

Path to output directory.

Return type:

Path

Raises:

  • ValueError â€“ If output directory exists and force=False, or if panel_column is not set (currently required).

  • OSError â€“ If directory cannot be created or files cannot be written.

Examples

>>> import pandas as pd
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> from trelliscope import Display
>>>
>>> # Create figures
>>> def make_plot(i):
...     fig, ax = plt.subplots()
...     ax.plot([1, 2, 3], [i, i*2, i*3])
...     return fig
>>>
>>> df = pd.DataFrame({
...     'plot': [make_plot(i) for i in range(3)],
...     'category': ['A', 'B', 'C'],
...     'value': [10, 20, 30]
... })
>>>
>>> display = (Display(df, name="example")
...     .set_panel_column("plot")
...     .infer_metas())
>>>
>>> # Write with panel rendering
>>> output_dir = display.write()
>>> print(output_dir)
./trelliscope_output/example
>>>
>>> # Panels saved to:
>>> # ./trelliscope_output/example/panels/0.png
>>> # ./trelliscope_output/example/panels/1.png
>>> # ./trelliscope_output/example/panels/2.png
set_viewer_config(config)[source]ïƒ

Set viewer configuration for display.

Configure viewer appearance and behavior including theme, initial sort/filter, and display options.

Parameters:

config (ViewerConfig or dict) â€“ Viewer configuration. Can be ViewerConfig object or dictionary with configuration options.

Returns:

Self for method chaining

Return type:

Display

Examples

>>> from trelliscope import Display
>>> from trelliscope.config import ViewerConfig
>>> import pandas as pd
>>>
>>> df = pd.DataFrame({'panel': ['a', 'b'], 'value': [1, 2]})
>>> display = Display(df, name="test").set_panel_column('panel')
>>>
>>> # Using ViewerConfig object
>>> config = ViewerConfig(theme="dark", show_info=False)
>>> display.set_viewer_config(config)
>>>
>>> # Using dictionary
>>> display.set_viewer_config({"theme": "light", "show_labels": True})
>>>
>>> # Using preset
>>> display.set_viewer_config(ViewerConfig.dark_theme())
>>>
>>> # With chaining
>>> display = (Display(df, name="test")
...     .set_panel_column('panel')
...     .set_viewer_config(ViewerConfig(theme="dark"))
...     .view())

See also

ViewerConfig

Configuration class with presets and validation

view(port=8000, open_browser=True, blocking=False, viewer_version='latest', force_write=False)[source]ïƒ

Launch interactive viewer for this display in a web browser.

Starts a local HTTP server and opens the display in a web browser for interactive exploration. The server serves the display files along with the trelliscopejs viewer loaded from CDN.

Parameters:

  • port (int, default=8000) â€“ Port number for the development server.

  • open_browser (bool, default=True) â€“ If True, automatically open the display in the default web browser. If False, just start the server and print the URL.

  • blocking (bool, default=False) â€“ If True, block execution until server is stopped (Ctrl+C). If False, run server in background thread and return immediately.

  • viewer_version (str, default="latest") â€“ Version of trelliscopejs-lib to use. Can be â€œlatestâ€ or specific version like â€œ2.0.0â€.

  • force_write (bool, default=False) â€“ If True, force rewriting the display even if it exists. If False, only write if not already written.

Returns:

URL where the display is being served.

Return type:

str

Raises:

  • ValueError â€“ If panel_column is not set.

  • OSError â€“ If server cannot start (e.g., port in use).

Examples

>>> import pandas as pd
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> from trelliscope import Display
>>>
>>> # Create and write display
>>> df = pd.DataFrame({
...     'plot': [make_plot(i) for i in range(5)],
...     'category': ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D', 'E']
... })
>>> display = (Display(df, name="my_display")
...     .set_panel_column("plot")
...     .infer_metas())
>>>
>>> # View in browser (non-blocking)
>>> url = display.view()
Display written to: ./trelliscope_output/my_display
Display available at: http://localhost:8000/index.html
Server running in background
>>>
>>> # Browser opens automatically, continue working...
>>> # Do other work while server runs
>>>
>>> # Or run in blocking mode (Ctrl+C to stop):
>>> display.view(blocking=True)
Serving display at http://localhost:8000/index.html
Press Ctrl+C to stop
^C
Shutting down server...

Notes

  • The server runs on localhost only (not accessible from other machines)

  • In non-blocking mode, the server runs in a background thread

  • Requires internet connection to load trelliscopejs-lib from CDN

  • Multiple displays can be viewed simultaneously on different ports

__repr__()[source]ïƒ

Return string representation of Display.

Return type:

str

Configure default grid layout for panels.

  • nrow (int, optional) â€“ Number of rows in the grid. If None, calculated automatically.

  • page (int, default=1) â€“ Starting page number.

  • arrangement ({"row", "col"}, default="row") â€“ Panel arrangement order (â€œrowâ€ for row-major, â€œcolâ€ for column-major).

Returns:

Self for method chaining.

Return type:

Display

Raises:

ValueError â€“ If ncol < 1, page < 1, or arrangement not in {â€œrowâ€, â€œcolâ€}.

Meta Variablesïƒ

Display.add_meta_def(varname, meta_type, replace=False, **kwargs)[source]ïƒ

Define and add a meta variable inline using type and parameters.

Parameters:

  • varname (str) â€“ Column name for meta variable.

  • meta_type (str) â€“ Meta type: â€œfactorâ€, â€œnumberâ€, â€œdateâ€, â€œtimeâ€, â€œcurrencyâ€, â€œhrefâ€, â€œgraphâ€.

  • replace (bool, default=False) â€“ If True, replace existing meta with same varname.

  • **kwargs â€“ Additional parameters for the meta type constructor.

Returns:

Self for method chaining.

Return type:

Display

Raises:

ValueError â€“ If meta_type is unknown or varname not in DataFrame.

Examples

>>> display.add_meta_def("category", "factor", levels=["A", "B", "C"])
>>> display.add_meta_def("value", "number", digits=3, log=True)
Display.infer_metas(columns=None, replace=False)[source]ïƒ

Automatically infer and add meta variables from DataFrame columns.

Parameters:

  • columns (list of str, optional) â€“ Columns to infer meta for. Defaults to all columns.

  • replace (bool, default=False) â€“ If True, replace existing metas for these columns.

Returns:

Self for method chaining.

Return type:

Display

Examples

>>> # Infer all columns
>>> display.infer_metas()
>>>
>>> # Infer specific columns
>>> display.infer_metas(columns=["category", "value"])

Viewsïƒ

Outputïƒ

Display.write(output_path=None, force=False, render_panels=True, create_index=True, viewer_debug=False, use_multi_display=True)[source]ïƒ

Write display to disk as JSON specification and render panels.

Creates output directory, renders panel files, and writes displayInfo.json, metaData.json, metaData.js, metadata.csv, and index.html files.

Parameters:

  • output_path (Path or str, optional) â€“ Output directory path. Uses display.path if not provided.

  • force (bool, default=False) â€“ If True, overwrite existing output directory. If False, raise error if directory exists.

  • render_panels (bool, default=True) â€“ If True, render panel objects to files (PNG, HTML, etc.). If False, only write JSON/CSV files without rendering panels.

  • create_index (bool, default=True) â€“ If True, automatically generate index.html viewer file. If False, skip index.html generation.

  • viewer_debug (bool, default=False) â€“ If True, include debug console in index.html for troubleshooting. Only used when create_index=True.

  • use_multi_display (bool, default=True) â€“ If True, use multi-display structure with config.json and displays/ subdirectory. If False, use single-display structure (EXPERIMENTAL).

Returns:

Path to output directory.

Return type:

Path

Raises:

  • ValueError â€“ If output directory exists and force=False, or if panel_column is not set (currently required).

  • OSError â€“ If directory cannot be created or files cannot be written.

Examples

>>> import pandas as pd
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> from trelliscope import Display
>>>
>>> # Create figures
>>> def make_plot(i):
...     fig, ax = plt.subplots()
...     ax.plot([1, 2, 3], [i, i*2, i*3])
...     return fig
>>>
>>> df = pd.DataFrame({
...     'plot': [make_plot(i) for i in range(3)],
...     'category': ['A', 'B', 'C'],
...     'value': [10, 20, 30]
... })
>>>
>>> display = (Display(df, name="example")
...     .set_panel_column("plot")
...     .infer_metas())
>>>
>>> # Write with panel rendering
>>> output_dir = display.write()
>>> print(output_dir)
./trelliscope_output/example
>>>
>>> # Panels saved to:
>>> # ./trelliscope_output/example/panels/0.png
>>> # ./trelliscope_output/example/panels/1.png
>>> # ./trelliscope_output/example/panels/2.png
Display.view(port=8000, open_browser=True, blocking=False, viewer_version='latest', force_write=False)[source]ïƒ

Launch interactive viewer for this display in a web browser.

Starts a local HTTP server and opens the display in a web browser for interactive exploration. The server serves the display files along with the trelliscopejs viewer loaded from CDN.

Parameters:

  • port (int, default=8000) â€“ Port number for the development server.

  • open_browser (bool, default=True) â€“ If True, automatically open the display in the default web browser. If False, just start the server and print the URL.

  • blocking (bool, default=False) â€“ If True, block execution until server is stopped (Ctrl+C). If False, run server in background thread and return immediately.

  • viewer_version (str, default="latest") â€“ Version of trelliscopejs-lib to use. Can be â€œlatestâ€ or specific version like â€œ2.0.0â€.

  • force_write (bool, default=False) â€“ If True, force rewriting the display even if it exists. If False, only write if not already written.

Returns:

URL where the display is being served.

Return type:

str

Raises:

  • ValueError â€“ If panel_column is not set.

  • OSError â€“ If server cannot start (e.g., port in use).

Examples

>>> import pandas as pd
>>> import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
>>> from trelliscope import Display
>>>
>>> # Create and write display
>>> df = pd.DataFrame({
...     'plot': [make_plot(i) for i in range(5)],
...     'category': ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D', 'E']
... })
>>> display = (Display(df, name="my_display")
...     .set_panel_column("plot")
...     .infer_metas())
>>>
>>> # View in browser (non-blocking)
>>> url = display.view()
Display written to: ./trelliscope_output/my_display
Display available at: http://localhost:8000/index.html
Server running in background
>>>
>>> # Browser opens automatically, continue working...
>>> # Do other work while server runs
>>>
>>> # Or run in blocking mode (Ctrl+C to stop):
>>> display.view(blocking=True)
Serving display at http://localhost:8000/index.html
Press Ctrl+C to stop
^C
Shutting down server...

Notes

  • The server runs on localhost only (not accessible from other machines)

  • In non-blocking mode, the server runs in a background thread

  • Requires internet connection to load trelliscopejs-lib from CDN

  • Multiple displays can be viewed simultaneously on different ports

Panel Optionsïƒ

Display.set_panel_options(width=None, height=None, aspect=None, force_size=False)[source]ïƒ

Configure panel dimensions and sizing behavior.

Parameters:

  • width (int, optional) â€“ Panel width in pixels.

  • height (int, optional) â€“ Panel height in pixels. Ignored if aspect is specified.

  • aspect (float, optional) â€“ Aspect ratio (width/height). Overrides height if specified.

  • force_size (bool, default=False) â€“ Force exact dimensions regardless of content.

Returns:

Self for method chaining.

Return type:

Display

Raises:

ValueError â€“ If width or height < 1, or aspect <= 0.

Examples

>>> display.set_panel_options(width=800, height=600)
>>> display.set_panel_options(width=800, aspect=1.5)  # 800x533

Examplesïƒ

Basic Displayïƒ

import pandas as pd
from trelliscope import Display

df = pd.DataFrame({
    'plot': [fig1, fig2, fig3],
    'category': ['A', 'B', 'C'],
    'value': [10, 20, 30]
})

display = Display(df, name="basic_example")
display.set_panel_column("plot")
display.write()

Fluent APIïƒ

display = (
    Display(df, name="fluent_example")
    .set_panel_column("plot")
    .set_default_layout(ncol=3, nrow=2)
    .set_default_labels(["category", "value"])
    .infer_metas()
    .write()
)

With Custom Metasïƒ

from trelliscope import Display, NumberMeta, FactorMeta

display = (
    Display(df, name="custom_meta_example")
    .set_panel_column("plot")
    .add_meta_def(FactorMeta("category", levels=["A", "B", "C"]))
    .add_meta_def(NumberMeta("value", digits=2))
    .write()
)

With Viewsïƒ

display = (
    Display(df, name="views_example")
    .set_panel_column("plot")
    .add_view(
        name="high_values",
        filter_list=[{"type": "range", "varname": "value", "min": 20}],
        sort_list=[{"varname": "value", "dir": "desc"}]
    )
    .write()
)

See Alsoïƒ

  • Meta Variables API - Meta variable types and inference

  • Panels API - Panel rendering and management

  • Serialization API - JSON output format
